The **American Civil War** was fought in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") from 1861 to 1865. The result of
a long-standing [controversy](/wiki/Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War "Origins
of the American Civil War") over [slavery](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States
"Slavery in the United States"), war broke out in April 1861, when
[Confederates](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America") attacked [Fort Sumter](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter "Battle of Fort
Sumter") in [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"), shortly
after [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") was
[inaugurated](/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Abraham_Lincoln "First inauguration
of Abraham Lincoln"). The nationalists of the
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)")
proclaimed loyalty to the U.S. Constitution. They faced
[secessionists](/wiki/Secession_in_the_United_States#Civil_War_era_political_and_legal_views_on_secession
"Secession in the United States") of the [Confederate States of
America](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of America"),
who advocated for states’ rights to perpetual slavery and its expansion in the
Americas.

Among the 34 [U.S. states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") in February 1861,
seven [Southern](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United States") [slave
states](/wiki/Slave_states_and_free_states "Slave states and free states")
individually declared their [secession](/wiki/Secession "Secession") from the
U.S. to form the Confederate States of America. The Confederacy grew to
include eleven states; it claimed two more [border
states](/wiki/Border_states_\(American_Civil_War\) "Border states \(American
Civil War\)") ([Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky") and
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri")), the [Indian
Territory](/wiki/Indian_Territory "Indian Territory"), and the southern
portions of the Union's western territories of
[Arizona](/wiki/Arizona_Territory "Arizona Territory") and [New
Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico_Territory "New Mexico Territory"), which was
organized and incorporated into the Confederacy as [Confederate
Arizona](/wiki/Confederate_Arizona "Confederate Arizona"). The Confederacy was
never diplomatically recognized by the [United States
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States"), nor was it recognized by any foreign country (although
Britain and France granted it [belligerent status](/wiki/Belligerent
"Belligerent")). The states that remained loyal, including the border states
where slavery was legal, were known as the _Union_ or the _North_.

The North and South quickly raised volunteer and conscription armies that
fought mostly in the South over four years. During this time many innovations
in warfare occurred, including the development and use of iron-clad ships,
ultimately changing naval strategy around the world. The Union finally won the
war when General [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee")
surrendered to General [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S.
Grant") at the [battle of Appomattox](/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House
"Battle of Appomattox Court House"), which triggered a series of
[surrenders](/wiki/Surrender_\(military\) "Surrender \(military\)") by
Confederate generals throughout the southern states. Four years of intense
combat left 620,000 to 750,000 soldiers dead, a higher number than the number
of American military deaths in both World Wars, [Korea](/wiki/Korean_War
"Korean War"), [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War"),
[Iraq](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War") and
[Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%93present\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–present\)") combined, and much of the South's
infrastructure was destroyed. The Confederacy
[collapsed](/wiki/Conclusion_of_the_American_Civil_War#Capture_of_President_Davis_.28May_10.29
"Conclusion of the American Civil War"), slavery [was
abolished](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation Proclamation"), and 4
million slaves were freed. The [Reconstruction Era](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era
"Reconstruction Era") (1863–1877) overlapped and followed the war, with the
process of restoring national unity, strengthening the national government,
and granting [civil rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights") to freed slaves
throughout the country. The Civil War is arguably the most studied and
[written about](/wiki/Bibliography_of_the_American_Civil_War "Bibliography of
the American Civil War") episode in [American
history](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States "History of the United States").

## Prelude to war

In the [1860 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1860 "United States
presidential election, 1860"),
[Republicans](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)"), led by [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham
Lincoln"), supported banning slavery in all the [U.S.
territories](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United
States"). The Southern states viewed this as a violation of their
constitutional rights and as the first step in a plan to eventually abolish
slavery. The three pro-Union candidates together received an overwhelming 82%
majority of the votes cast nationally: Republican Lincoln's votes centered in
the north, [Democrat](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic
Party \(United States\)") [Stephen A. Douglas](/wiki/Stephen_A._Douglas
"Stephen A. Douglas")' votes were distributed nationally and [Constitutional
Unionist](/wiki/Constitutional_Union_Party_\(United_States\) "Constitutional
Union Party \(United States\)") [John
Bell](/wiki/John_Bell_\(Tennessee_politician\) "John Bell \(Tennessee
politician\)")'s votes centered in [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee"),
[Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"), and [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia
"Virginia"). The Republican Party, dominant in the North, secured a
[plurality](/wiki/Plurality_\(voting\) "Plurality \(voting\)") of the popular
votes and a majority of the electoral votes nationally, so Lincoln was
constitutionally elected president. He was the first Republican Party
candidate to win the presidency. However, before [his
inauguration](/wiki/First_inauguration_of_Abraham_Lincoln "First inauguration
of Abraham Lincoln"), seven slave states with [cotton](/wiki/Cotton
"Cotton")-based economies declared secession and formed the
[Confederacy](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America"). The first six to declare secession had the highest proportions of
slaves in their populations, a total of 49 percent.[16] The first seven with
state legislatures to resolve for secession included split majorities for
unionists Douglas and Bell in [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_\(U.S._state\) "Georgia
\(U.S. state\)") with 51% and [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") with
55%. [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama "Alabama") had voted 46% for those unionists,
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi") with 40%,
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") with 38%, [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") with
25%, and [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina") cast
[Electoral College](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\) "Electoral
College \(United States\)") votes without a popular vote for president.[17] Of
these, only Texas held a referendum on secession.

Eight remaining slave states continued to reject calls for secession. Outgoing
Democratic President [James Buchanan](/wiki/James_Buchanan "James Buchanan")
and the incoming Republicans rejected secession as illegal. [Lincoln's March
4, 1861, inaugural address](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln%27s_first_inaugural_address
"Abraham Lincoln's first inaugural address") declared that his administration
would not initiate a [civil war](/wiki/Civil_war "Civil war"). Speaking
directly to the "Southern States", he reaffirmed, "I have no purpose, directly
or indirectly to interfere with the institution of slavery in the United
States where it exists. I believe I have no lawful right to do so, and I have
no inclination to do so."[18] After Confederate forces seized numerous federal
forts within territory claimed by the Confederacy, efforts at compromise
failed and both sides prepared for war. The Confederates assumed that
[European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") countries were so dependent on "[King
Cotton](/wiki/King_Cotton "King Cotton")" that they would intervene, but none
did, and none recognized the new Confederate States of America.

Hostilities began on April 12, 1861, when Confederate forces [fired upon Fort
Sumter](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter "Battle of Fort Sumter"). While in the
[Western Theater](/wiki/Western_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Western
Theater of the American Civil War") the Union made significant permanent
gains, in the [Eastern
Theater](/wiki/Eastern_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Eastern Theater of
the American Civil War"), the battle was inconclusive from 1861–1862. Lincoln
issued the [Emancipation Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation
"Emancipation Proclamation"), which made ending slavery a war goal.[19] To the
west, by summer 1862 the Union destroyed the Confederate river navy, then much
of their western armies, and seized [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans"). The 1863 Union [Siege of Vicksburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege
of Vicksburg") split the Confederacy in two at the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). In 1863, [Robert E.
Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee")'s Confederate incursion north ended
at the [Battle of Gettysburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg "Battle of
Gettysburg"). Western successes led to [Ulysses S.
Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant")'s command of all Union
armies in 1864. Inflicting an ever-tightening [naval
blockade](/wiki/Union_blockade "Union blockade") of Confederate ports, the
Union marshaled the resources and manpower to attack the Confederacy from all
directions, leading to the [fall of Atlanta](/wiki/Fall_of_Atlanta "Fall of
Atlanta") to [William T. Sherman](/wiki/William_T._Sherman "William T.
Sherman") and [his march to the sea](/wiki/Sherman%27s_march_to_the_sea
"Sherman's march to the sea"). The last significant battles raged around the
[Siege of Petersburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Petersburg "Siege of Petersburg"). Lee's
escape attempt ended with his [surrender at Appomattox Court
House](/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House "Battle of Appomattox Court
House"), on April 9, 1865. While the military war was coming to an end, the
political reintegration of the nation was to take another 12 years, known as
the [Reconstruction Era](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era "Reconstruction Era").

The American Civil War was one of the earliest true [industrial
wars](/wiki/Industrial_warfare "Industrial warfare"). Railroads, the
[telegraph](/wiki/Telegraph "Telegraph"), steamships and [iron-
clad](/wiki/Ironclad_warship "Ironclad warship") ships, and mass-produced
weapons were employed extensively. The mobilization of civilian factories,
mines, shipyards, banks, transportation and food supplies all foreshadowed the
impact of industrialization in [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"),
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and subsequent conflicts. It
remains the deadliest war in [American
history](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States "History of the United States").
From 1861 to 1865, it is estimated that 620,000 to 750,000 soldiers died[20],
along with an undetermined number of [civilians](/wiki/Civilian_casualties
"Civilian casualties").[a] By one estimate, the war claimed the lives of 10
percent of all Northern males 20–45 years old, and 30 percent of all Southern
white males aged 18–40.[22]

## Causes of secession

Main articles: [Origins of the American Civil
War](/wiki/Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War "Origins of the American Civil
War") and [Timeline of events leading to the American Civil
War](/wiki/Timeline_of_events_leading_to_the_American_Civil_War "Timeline of
events leading to the American Civil War")

The causes of the Civil War were complex and have been controversial since the
war began. James C. Bradford wrote that the issue has been further complicated
by [historical revisionists](/wiki/Historical_revisionism "Historical
revisionism"), who have tried to offer a variety of reasons for the war.[23]
Slavery was the central source of escalating political tension in the
[1850s](/wiki/1850s_in_the_United_States "1850s in the United States"). The
[Republican Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)") was determined to prevent any spread of slavery, and many
Southern leaders had threatened secession if the Republican candidate,
[Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln"), won the [1860
election](/wiki/1860_U.S._Presidential_election "1860 U.S. Presidential
election"). After Lincoln won without carrying a single Southern state, many
[Southern whites](/wiki/Definitions_of_whiteness_in_the_United_States
"Definitions of whiteness in the United States") felt that disunion had become
their only option, because they thought that they were losing representation,
which would hamper their ability to promote pro-slavery acts and
policies.[24][25]

Territories

Slavery was a major cause of disunion [26]. Although there were opposing views
even in the Union States[27][28], most northern soldiers were largely
indifferent on the subject of slavery [29], while Confederates fought the war,
in large measure, to protect southern society, and slavery was an integral
part of it.[30] From the anti-slavery perspective, the issue was primarily
about whether the system of slavery was an anachronistic evil that was
incompatible with [republicanism](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States
"Republicanism in the United States"). The strategy of the anti-slavery forces
was containment—to stop the expansion and thus put slavery on a path to
gradual extinction.[31] The slave-holding interests in the South denounced
this strategy as infringing upon their Constitutional rights.[32] Southern
whites believed that the emancipation of slaves would destroy the South's
economy, due to the large amount of capital invested in slaves and fears of
integrating the ex-slave black population.[33]

Slavery was illegal in much of the North, having been outlawed in the late
18th and early 19th centuries. It was also fading in the border states and in
Southern cities, but it was expanding in the highly profitable cotton
districts of the rural South and Southwest. Subsequent writers on the American
Civil War looked to several factors explaining the geographic divide.

### Sectionalism

[Sectionalism](/wiki/Sectionalism "Sectionalism") refers to the different
economies, social structure, customs and political values of the North and
South.[34][35] It increased steadily between 1800 and 1860 as the North, which
phased slavery out of existence, industrialized, urbanized, and built
prosperous farms, while the deep South concentrated on plantation agriculture
based on slave labor, together with [subsistence
farming](/wiki/Subsistence_farming "Subsistence farming") for poor
[freedmen](/wiki/Freedman "Freedman"). In the 1840s and 50s, the issue of
accepting slavery (in the guise of rejecting slave-owning bishops and
missionaries) split the nation's largest religious denominations (the
Methodist, Baptist and Presbyterian churches) into separate Northern and
Southern denominations.[36]

Historians have debated whether economic differences between the industrial
Northeast and the agricultural South helped cause the war. Most historians now
disagree with the [economic determinism](/wiki/Economic_determinism "Economic
determinism") of historian [Charles A. Beard](/wiki/Charles_A._Beard "Charles
A. Beard") in the 1920s and emphasize that Northern and Southern economies
were largely complementary. While socially different, the sections
economically benefited each other.[37][38]

### Protectionism

Historically, southern slave-holding states, because of their low cost manual
labor, had little perceived need for mechanization, and supported having the
right to sell cotton and purchase manufactured goods from any nation. Northern
states, which had heavily invested in their still-nascent manufacturing, could
not compete with the full-fledged industries of Europe in offering high prices
for cotton imported from the South and low prices for manufactured exports in
return. Thus, northern manufacturing interests supported tariffs and
protectionism while southern planters demanded free trade.[39]

The Democrats in Congress, controlled by Southerners, wrote the tariff laws in
the 1830s, 1840s, and 1850s, and kept reducing rates so that the 1857 rates
were the lowest since 1816. The Whigs and Republicans complained because they
favored high tariffs to stimulate industrial growth, and Republicans called
for an increase in tariffs in the 1860 election. The increases were only
enacted in 1861 after Southerners resigned their seats in Congress.[40][41]
The tariff issue was and is sometimes cited–long after the war–by [Lost
Cause](/wiki/Lost_Cause "Lost Cause") historians and [neo-
Confederate](/wiki/Neo-Confederate "Neo-Confederate") apologists. In 1860–61
none of the groups that proposed compromises to head off secession raised the
tariff issue.[42] Pamphleteers North and South rarely mentioned the
tariff,[43] and when some did, for instance, [Matthew Fontaine
Maury](/wiki/Matthew_Fontaine_Maury "Matthew Fontaine Maury")[44] and [John
Lothrop Motley](/wiki/John_Lothrop_Motley "John Lothrop Motley"),[45] they
were generally writing for a foreign audience.

### States' rights

The South argued that each state had the right to secede—leave the Union—at
any time, that the Constitution was a "compact" or agreement among the states.
Northerners (including President Buchanan) rejected that notion as opposed to
the will of the Founding Fathers who said they were setting up a perpetual
union.[46] Historian James McPherson writes concerning states' rights and
other non-slavery explanations:

> While one or more of these interpretations remain popular among the [Sons of
> Confederate Veterans](/wiki/Sons_of_Confederate_Veterans "Sons of
> Confederate Veterans") and other Southern heritage groups, few professional
> historians now subscribe to them. Of all these interpretations, the
> states'-rights argument is perhaps the weakest. It fails to ask the
> question, states' rights for what purpose? States' rights, or sovereignty,
> was always more a means than an end, an instrument to achieve a certain goal
> more than a principle.[47]

### Territorial crisis

Further information: [Slave and free states](/wiki/Slave_and_free_states
"Slave and free states")

Between 1803 and 1854, the United States achieved a vast expansion of
territory through purchase, negotiation, and conquest. At first, the new
states carved out of these territories entering the union were apportioned
equally between slave and free states. It was over territories west of the
Mississippi that the proslavery and antislavery forces collided.[48]

With the conquest of northern [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") west to
[California](/wiki/Alta_California "Alta California") in 1848, slaveholding
interests looked forward to expanding into these lands and perhaps Cuba and
Central America as well.[49][50] Northern "free soil" interests vigorously
sought to curtail any further expansion of slave territory. The [Compromise of
1850](/wiki/Compromise_of_1850 "Compromise of 1850") over California balanced
a free soil state with stronger fugitive slave laws for a political settlement
after four years of strife in the 1840s. But the states admitted following
California were all free: Minnesota (1858), Oregon (1859) and Kansas (1861).
In the southern states the question of the territorial expansion of slavery
westward again became explosive.[51] Both the South and the North drew the
same conclusion: "The power to decide the question of slavery for the
territories was the power to determine the future of slavery itself."[52][53]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Stephen_Arnold_Douglas.jpg/150px-
Stephen_Arnold_Douglas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stephen_Arnold_Douglas.jpg)

Sen. Stephen Douglas, author of the [Kansas–Nebraska
Act](/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act "Kansas–Nebraska Act") of 1854

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/John_J._Crittenden_-
_Brady-Handy.jpg/140px-John_J._Crittenden_-_Brady-
Handy.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_J._Crittenden_-_Brady-Handy.jpg)

Sen. John J. Crittenden, of the 1860 [Crittenden
Compromise](/wiki/Crittenden_Compromise "Crittenden Compromise")

By 1860, four doctrines had emerged to answer the question of federal control
in the territories, and they all claimed they were sanctioned by the
Constitution, implicitly or explicitly.[54] The first of these "conservative"
theories, represented by the [Constitutional Union
Party](/wiki/Constitutional_Union_Party_\(United_States\) "Constitutional
Union Party \(United States\)"), argued that the [Missouri
Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri Compromise") apportionment of
territory north for free soil and south for slavery should become a
Constitutional mandate. The [Crittenden
Compromise](/wiki/Crittenden_Compromise "Crittenden Compromise") of 1860 was
an expression of this view.[55]

The second doctrine of Congressional preeminence, championed by Abraham
Lincoln and the Republican Party, insisted that the Constitution did not bind
legislators to a policy of balance—that slavery could be excluded in a
territory as it was done in the [Northwest
Ordinance](/wiki/Northwest_Ordinance "Northwest Ordinance") of 1787 at the
discretion of Congress,[56] thus Congress could restrict human bondage, but
never establish it. The [Wilmot Proviso](/wiki/Wilmot_Proviso "Wilmot
Proviso") announced this position in 1846.[57]

Senator [Stephen A. Douglas](/wiki/Stephen_A._Douglas "Stephen A. Douglas")
proclaimed the doctrine of territorial or "popular" sovereignty—which asserted
that the settlers in a territory had the same rights as states in the Union to
establish or disestablish slavery as a purely local matter.[58] The
[Kansas–Nebraska Act](/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act "Kansas–Nebraska Act")
of 1854 legislated this doctrine.[59] In Kansas Territory, years of [pro and
anti-slavery violence](/wiki/Bleeding_Kansas "Bleeding Kansas") and political
conflict erupted; the congressional House of Representatives voted to admit
Kansas as a free state in early 1860, but its admission in the Senate was
delayed until January 1861, after the 1860 elections when southern senators
began to leave.[60]

The fourth theory was advocated by Mississippi Senator [Jefferson
Davis](/wiki/Jefferson_Davis "Jefferson Davis"),[61] one of state sovereignty
("states' rights"),[62] also known as the "Calhoun doctrine",[63] named after
the South Carolinian political theorist and statesman [John C.
Calhoun](/wiki/John_Caldwell_Calhoun "John Caldwell Calhoun").[64] Rejecting
the arguments for federal authority or self-government, state sovereignty
would empower states to promote the expansion of slavery as part of the
Federal Union under the U.S. Constitution.[65] "States' rights" was an
ideology formulated and applied as a means of advancing slave state interests
through federal authority.[66] As historian Thomas L. Krannawitter points out,
the "Southern demand for federal slave protection represented a demand for an
unprecedented expansion of federal power."[67][68] These four doctrines
comprised the major ideologies presented to the American public on the matters
of slavery, the territories and the U.S. Constitution prior to the 1860
presidential election.[69]

### National elections

Beginning in the [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American
Revolution") and accelerating after the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War
of 1812"), the people of the United States grew in the sense that their
country was a national republic based on the belief that all people had
inalienable political liberty and personal rights which could serve as an
important example to the rest of the world. Previous regional independence
movements such as the [Greek revolt](/wiki/Greek_War_of_Independence "Greek
War of Independence") in the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman
Empire"), the division and redivision of the Latin American political map, and
the British-French [Crimean triumph](/wiki/Crimean_War "Crimean War") leading
to an interest in redrawing Europe along cultural differences, all conspired
to make for a time of upheaval and uncertainty about the basis of the nation-
state.

In the world of 19th century self-made Americans, growing in prosperity,
population and expanding westward, "freedom" could mean personal liberty or
property rights. The unresolved difference would cause failure—first in their
political institutions, then in their civil life together.

#### Nationalism and honor

[![Middle-aged man in a beard posed sitting in a suit, vest and
bowtie](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Abraham_Lincoln_seated%2C_Feb_9%2C_1864.jpg/220px-
Abraham_Lincoln_seated%2C_Feb_9%2C_1864.jpg)](/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_seated,_Feb_9,_1864.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Abraham_Lincoln_seated,_Feb_9,_1864.jpg "Enlarge")

[Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln")  
16th U.S. President (1861–1865)

Nationalism was a powerful force in the early 19th century, with famous
spokesmen such as [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson") and
[Daniel Webster](/wiki/Daniel_Webster "Daniel Webster"). While practically all
Northerners supported the Union, Southerners were split between those loyal to
the entire United States (called "unionists") and those loyal primarily to the
southern region and then the Confederacy.[70] [C. Vann
Woodward](/wiki/C._Vann_Woodward "C. Vann Woodward") said of the latter group,

> A great slave society ... had grown up and miraculously flourished in the
> heart of a thoroughly bourgeois and partly puritanical republic. It had
> renounced its bourgeois origins and elaborated and painfully rationalized
> its institutional, legal, metaphysical, and religious defenses ... When the
> crisis came it chose to fight. It proved to be the death struggle of a
> society, which went down in ruins.[71]

Perceived insults to Southern collective honor included the enormous
popularity of _[Uncle Tom's Cabin](/wiki/Uncle_Tom%27s_Cabin "Uncle Tom's
Cabin")_ (1852)[72] and the actions of abolitionist [John
Brown](/wiki/John_Brown_\(abolitionist\) "John Brown \(abolitionist\)") in
trying to incite a [slave
rebellion](/wiki/John_Brown%27s_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry "John Brown's raid on
Harpers Ferry") in 1859.[73]

While the South moved towards a Southern nationalism, leaders in the North
were also becoming more nationally minded, and they rejected any notion of
splitting the Union. The Republican national electoral platform of 1860 warned
that Republicans regarded disunion as [treason](/wiki/Treason "Treason") and
would not tolerate it: "We denounce those threats of disunion ... as denying
the vital principles of a free government, and as an avowal of contemplated
treason, which it is the imperative duty of an indignant people sternly to
rebuke and forever silence."[74] The South ignored the warnings: Southerners
did not realize how ardently the North would fight to hold the Union
together.[75]

#### Lincoln's election

Main article: [United States presidential election,
1860](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1860 "United States
presidential election, 1860")

The election of Abraham Lincoln in November 1860 was the final trigger for
secession.[76] Efforts at compromise, including the "[Corwin
Amendment](/wiki/Corwin_Amendment "Corwin Amendment")" and the "[Crittenden
Compromise](/wiki/Crittenden_Compromise "Crittenden Compromise")", failed.
Southern leaders feared that Lincoln would stop the expansion of slavery and
put it on a course toward extinction. The slave states, which had already
become a minority in the House of Representatives, were now facing a future as
a perpetual minority in the Senate and Electoral College against an
increasingly powerful North. Before Lincoln took office in March 1861, seven
slave states had declared their secession and joined to form the Confederacy.

According to Lincoln, the people of the United States had shown that they can
be successful in _establishing_ and _administering_ a republic, but a third
challenge faced the nation, _maintaining_ the republic, based on the people's
vote. The people must now show: ". . . successful maintenance [of the
Republic] against a formidable internal attempt to overthrow it. It is now for
them to demonstrate to the world that those who can fairly carry an election
can also suppress a rebellion; that ballots are the rightful and peaceful
successors of bullets; and that when ballots have fairly and constitutionally
decided, there can be no successful appeal back to bullets; that there can be
no successful appeal, except to ballots themselves, at succeeding elections.
Such will be a great lesson of peace; teaching men that what they cannot take
by an election, neither can they take it by a war . . .." [77]

## Outbreak of the war

### Secession crisis

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Charleston_Mercury_Secession_Broadside%2C_1860.jpg/170px-
Charleston_Mercury_Secession_Broadside%2C_1860.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charleston_Mercury_Secession_Broadside,_1860.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charleston_Mercury_Secession_Broadside,_1860.jpg "Enlarge")

The first published imprint of secession

The election of Lincoln caused the legislature of South Carolina to call a
state convention to consider secession. Prior to the war, South Carolina did
more than any other Southern state to advance the notion that a state had the
right to [nullify](/wiki/Nullification_\(U.S._Constitution\) "Nullification
\(U.S. Constitution\)") federal laws and, even, secede from the United States.
The convention summoned unanimously voted to secede on December 20, 1860, and
adopted the "[Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the
Secession of South Carolina from the Federal
Union](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Immediate_Causes_Which_Induce_and_Justify_the_Secession_of_South_Carolina_from_the_Federal_Union
"Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of
South Carolina from the Federal Union")". It argued for states' rights for
slave owners in the South, but contained a complaint about states' rights in
the North in the form of opposition to the [Fugitive Slave
Act](/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Law_of_1850 "Fugitive Slave Law of 1850"), claiming
that Northern states were not fulfilling their federal obligations under the
Constitution. The "cotton states" of Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia,
Louisiana, and Texas followed suit, seceding in January and February 1861.

Among the ordinances of secession passed by the individual states, those of
three—Texas, Alabama, and Virginia—specifically mentioned the plight of the
'slaveholding states' at the hands of northern abolitionists. The rest make no
mention of the slavery issue, and are often brief announcements of the
dissolution of ties by the legislatures.[78] However, at least four
states—South Carolina,[79] Mississippi,[80] Georgia,[81] and Texas[82] also
passed lengthy and detailed explanations of their causes for secession, all of
which laid the blame squarely on the movement to abolish slavery and that
movement's influence over the politics of the northern states. The southern
states believed slaveholding was a constitutional right because of the
[Fugitive slave clause](/wiki/Fugitive_slave_clause "Fugitive slave clause")
of the Constitution.

These states agreed to form a new federal government, the [Confederate States
of America](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America"), on February 4, 1861.[83] They took control of federal forts and
other properties within their boundaries with little resistance from outgoing
President [James Buchanan](/wiki/James_Buchanan "James Buchanan"), whose term
ended on March 4, 1861. Buchanan said that the [Dred Scott
decision](/wiki/Dred_Scott_decision "Dred Scott decision") was proof that the
South had no reason for secession, and that the Union "... was intended to be
perpetual," but that, "The power by force of arms to compel a State to remain
in the Union," was not among the "... enumerated powers granted to
Congress."[84] One quarter of the U.S. Army—the entire garrison in Texas—was
surrendered in February 1861 to state forces by its commanding general, [David
E. Twiggs](/wiki/David_E._Twiggs "David E. Twiggs"), who then joined the
Confederacy.

As Southerners resigned their seats in the Senate and the House, Republicans
were able to pass bills for projects that had been blocked by Southern
Senators before the war, including the [Morrill Tariff](/wiki/Morrill_Tariff
"Morrill Tariff"), land grant colleges (the [Morrill Act](/wiki/Morrill_Land-
Grant_Colleges_Act "Morrill Land-Grant Colleges Act")), a [Homestead
Act](/wiki/Homestead_Act "Homestead Act"), a transcontinental railroad (the
[Pacific Railway Acts](/wiki/Pacific_Railway_Acts "Pacific Railway
Acts")),[85] the [National Banking Act](/wiki/National_Banking_Act "National
Banking Act") and the authorization of [United States
Notes](/wiki/United_States_Note "United States Note") by the Legal Tender Act
of 1862. The [Revenue Act of 1861](/wiki/Revenue_Act_of_1861 "Revenue Act of
1861") introduced the [income tax](/wiki/Income_tax "Income tax") to help
finance the war.

On December 18, 1860, the [Crittenden Compromise](/wiki/Crittenden_Compromise
"Crittenden Compromise") was proposed to re-establish the [Missouri
Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri Compromise") line by
constitutionally banning slavery in territories to the north of the line while
guaranteeing it to the south. The adoption of this compromise likely would
have prevented the secession of every southern state apart from South
Carolina, but Lincoln and the Republicans rejected it.[86] It was then
proposed to hold a national referendum on the compromise. The Republicans
again rejected the idea, although a majority of both Northerners and
Southerners would have voted in favor of it.[87] A pre-war February [Peace
Conference of 1861](/wiki/Peace_Conference_of_1861 "Peace Conference of 1861")
met in Washington, proposing a solution similar to that of the Crittenden
compromise, it was rejected by Congress. The Republicans proposed an
[alternative compromise](/wiki/Corwin_amendment "Corwin amendment") to not
interfere with slavery where it existed but the South regarded it as
insufficient. Nonetheless, the remaining eight slave states rejected pleas to
join the Confederacy following a two-to-one no-vote in Virginia's First
Secessionist Convention on April 4, 1861.[88]

Jefferson-Davis.jpg/170px-President-Jefferson-

[](/wiki/File:President-Jefferson-Davis.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jefferson Davis](/wiki/Jefferson_Davis "Jefferson Davis"), [President of the
Confederate States of
America](/wiki/President_of_the_Confederate_States_of_America "President of

On March 4, 1861, [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln")
was sworn in as President. In his [inaugural address](/wiki/Inauguration
"Inauguration"), he argued that the Constitution was a _[more perfect
union](/wiki/Preamble_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Preamble to the
United States Constitution")_ than the earlier [Articles of Confederation and
Perpetual Union](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation"),
that it was a binding contract, and called any secession "legally void".[89]
He had no intent to invade Southern states, nor did he intend to end slavery
where it existed, but said that he would use force to maintain possession of
Federal property. The government would make no move to recover post offices,
and if resisted, mail delivery would end at state lines. Where popular
conditions did not allow peaceful enforcement of Federal law, U.S. Marshals
and Judges would be withdrawn. No mention was made of bullion lost from U.S.
mints in Louisiana, Georgia and North Carolina. In Lincoln's inaugural
address, he stated that it would be U.S. policy to only collect import duties
at its ports; there could be no serious injury to the South to justify armed
revolution during his administration. His speech closed with a plea for
restoration of the bonds of union, famously calling on "the mystic chords of
memory" binding the two regions.[90]

The South sent delegations to Washington and offered to pay for the federal
properties and enter into a peace treaty with the United States. Lincoln
rejected any negotiations with Confederate agents because he claimed the
Confederacy was not a legitimate government, and that making any treaty with
it would be tantamount to recognition of it as a sovereign government.[91]
Secretary of State [William Seward](/wiki/William_H._Seward "William H.
Seward") who at that time saw himself as the real governor or "prime minister"
behind the throne of the inexperienced Lincoln, engaged in unauthorized and
indirect negotiations that failed.[91] President Lincoln was determined to
hold all remaining Union-occupied forts in the Confederacy, [Fort
Monroe](/wiki/Fort_Monroe "Fort Monroe") in Virginia, in Florida, [Fort
Pickens](/wiki/Fort_Pickens "Fort Pickens"), [Fort
Jefferson](/wiki/Fort_Jefferson,_Florida "Fort Jefferson, Florida"), and [Fort
Taylor](/wiki/Fort_Zachary_Taylor "Fort Zachary Taylor"), and in the cockpit
of secession, Charleston, South Carolina's [Fort Sumter](/wiki/Fort_Sumter
"Fort Sumter").

### Battle of Fort Sumter

Main article: [Battle of Fort Sumter](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter "Battle of
Fort Sumter")

[![Crowd surrounding an equestrian statue topped by a huge U.S.
flag](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Great_Meeting_Union_Square.jpg/300px-
Great_Meeting_Union_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Great_Meeting_Union_Square.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Great_Meeting_Union_Square.jpg "Enlarge")

Mass meeting April 20, 1861, to support the Government at Washington's
equestrian statue in [Union Square](/wiki/Union_Square_\(New_York_City\)
"Union Square \(New York City\)") NYC

Fort Sumter was located in the middle of the harbor of
[Charleston](/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina_in_the_American_Civil_War
"Charleston, South Carolina in the American Civil War"), South Carolina, where
the U.S. fort's garrison had withdrawn to avoid incidents with local militias
in the streets of the city. Unlike Buchanan, who allowed commanders to
relinquish possession to avoid bloodshed, Lincoln required Maj. Anderson to
hold on until fired upon. Jefferson Davis ordered the surrender of the fort.
Anderson gave a conditional reply that the Confederate government rejected,
and Davis ordered [P. G. T. Beauregard](/wiki/P._G._T._Beauregard "P. G. T.
Beauregard") to attack the fort before a relief expedition could arrive.
Troops under Beauregard bombarded Fort Sumter on April 12–13, forcing its
capitulation.

The attack on Fort Sumter rallied the North to the defense of American
nationalism. Historian [Allan Nevins](/wiki/Allan_Nevins "Allan Nevins") said:

    The thunderclap of Sumter produced a startling crystallization of Northern sentiment. ... Anger swept the land. From every side came news of mass meetings, speeches, resolutions, tenders of business support, the muster of companies and regiments, the determined action of governors and legislatures."[92][93]

However, much of the North's attitude was based on the false belief that only
a minority of Southerners were actually in favor of secession and that there
were large numbers of southern Unionists that could be counted on. Had
Northerners realized that most Southerners really did favor secession, they
might have hesitated at attempting the enormous task of conquering a united
South.[94]

Lincoln called on all the states to send forces to recapture the fort and
other federal properties. With the scale of the rebellion apparently small so
far, Lincoln called for only [75,000 volunteers](/wiki/75,000_volunteers
"75,000 volunteers") for 90 days.[95] The governor of Massachusetts had state
regiments on trains headed south the next day. In western Missouri, local
secessionists seized [Liberty Arsenal](/wiki/Liberty_Arsenal "Liberty
Arsenal").[96] On May 3, 1861, Lincoln called for an additional 42,000
volunteers for a period of three years.[97]

Four states in the middle and upper South had repeatedly rejected Confederate
overtures, but now [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia_in_the_American_Civil_War
"Virginia in the American Civil War"),
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee_in_the_American_Civil_War "Tennessee in the
American Civil War"), [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas_in_the_American_Civil_War
"Arkansas in the American Civil War"), and [North
Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina_in_the_American_Civil_War "North Carolina in
the American Civil War") refused to send forces against their neighbors,
declared their secession, and joined the Confederacy. To reward Virginia, the
Confederate capital was moved to [Richmond](/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia
"Richmond, Virginia").[98]

### Attitude of the border states

Main article: [Border states (American Civil
War)](/wiki/Border_states_\(American_Civil_War\) "Border states \(American
Civil War\)")

[Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"), [Delaware](/wiki/Delaware "Delaware"),
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), and [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky
"Kentucky") were slave states that were opposed to both secession and coercing
the South. [West Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia") then joined
them as an additional border state after it separated from
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") and became a state of the
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)") in
1863.

Maryland's territory surrounded the United States' capital of [Washington,
DC](/wiki/Washington_DC_in_the_Civil_War "Washington DC in the Civil War") and
could cut it off from the North.[99] It had numerous anti-Lincoln officials
who tolerated anti-army [rioting in Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore_riot_of_1861
"Baltimore riot of 1861") and the burning of bridges, both aimed at hindering
the passage of troops to the South. Maryland's legislature voted
overwhelmingly (53–13) to stay in the Union, but also rejected hostilities
with its southern neighbors, voting to close Maryland's rail lines to prevent
them from being used for war.[100] Lincoln responded by establishing [martial
law](/wiki/Martial_law "Martial law"), and unilaterally suspending [habeas
corpus](/wiki/Habeas_corpus "Habeas corpus"), in Maryland, along with sending
in militia units from the North.[101] Lincoln rapidly took control of Maryland
and the District of Columbia, by seizing many prominent figures, including
arresting 1/3 of the members of the [Maryland General
Assembly](/wiki/Maryland_General_Assembly "Maryland General Assembly") on the
day it reconvened.[100][102] All were held without trial, ignoring a ruling by
the Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court [Roger Taney](/wiki/Roger_Taney
"Roger Taney"), a Maryland native, that only Congress (and not the president)
could suspend habeas corpus ([Ex parte Merryman](/wiki/Ex_parte_Merryman "Ex
parte Merryman")). Indeed, federal troops imprisoned a prominent Baltimore
newspaper editor, [Frank Key Howard](/wiki/Frank_Key_Howard "Frank Key
Howard"), Francis Scott Key's grandson, after he criticized Lincoln in an
editorial for ignoring the Supreme Court Chief Justice's ruling.[103]

In Missouri, an [elected
convention](/wiki/Missouri_Constitutional_Convention_\(1861%E2%80%9363\)
"Missouri Constitutional Convention \(1861–63\)") on secession voted
decisively to remain within the Union. When pro-Confederate Governor
[Claiborne F. Jackson](/wiki/Claiborne_Fox_Jackson "Claiborne Fox Jackson")
called out the state militia, it was attacked by federal forces under General
[Nathaniel Lyon](/wiki/Nathaniel_Lyon "Nathaniel Lyon"), who chased the
governor and the rest of the State Guard to the southwestern corner of the
state. (_See also:[Missouri secession](/wiki/Missouri_secession "Missouri
secession")_). In the resulting vacuum, the convention on secession reconvened
and took power as the Unionist provisional government of Missouri.[104]

Kentucky did not secede; for a time, it declared itself neutral. When
Confederate forces entered the state in September 1861, neutrality ended and
the state reaffirmed its Union status, while trying to maintain slavery.
During a brief invasion by Confederate forces, Confederate sympathizers
organized a secession convention, inaugurated a governor, and gained
recognition from the Confederacy. The rebel government soon went into exile
and never controlled Kentucky.[105]

After Virginia's secession, a [Unionist
government](/wiki/Restored_Government_of_Virginia "Restored Government of
Virginia") in [Wheeling](/wiki/Wheeling,_West_Virginia "Wheeling, West
Virginia") asked 48 counties to vote on an ordinance to create a new state on
October 24, 1861. A voter turnout of 34 percent approved the statehood bill
(96 percent approving).[106] The inclusion of 24 secessionist counties[107] in
the state and the ensuing guerrilla war engaged about 40,000 Federal troops
for much of the war.[108][109] Congress admitted [West
Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia") to the Union on June 20, 1863.
West Virginia provided about 20,000–22,000 soldiers to both the Confederacy
and the Union.[110]

A Unionist secession attempt occurred in [East Tennessee](/wiki/East_Tennessee
"East Tennessee"), but was suppressed by the Confederacy, which arrested over
3,000 men suspected of being loyal to the Union. They were held without
trial.[111]

battles](/wiki/List_of_American_Civil_War_battles "List of American Civil War
battles") and [Military leadership in the American Civil
War](/wiki/Military_leadership_in_the_American_Civil_War "Military leadership
in the American Civil War")

American_Civil_War_Battles_by_Theater%2C_Year.png)](/wiki/File:American_Civil_War_Battles_by_Theater,_Year.png)

[](/wiki/File:American_Civil_War_Battles_by_Theater,_Year.png "Enlarge")

[County](/wiki/County_\(United_States\) "County \(United States\)") map of
Civil War battles by theater and year

The Civil War was a contest marked by the ferocity and frequency of battle.
Over four years, 237 named battles were fought, as were many more minor
actions and skirmishes, which were often characterized by their bitter
intensity and high casualties. In his book _The American Civil War_ , John
Keegan writes that "The American Civil War was to prove one of the most
ferocious wars ever fought". Without geographic objectives, the only target
for each side was the enemy's soldier.[112]

### Mobilization

As the first seven states began organizing a Confederacy in Montgomery, the
entire U.S. army numbered 16,000. However, Northern governors had begun to
mobilize their militias.[113] The Confederate Congress authorized the new
nation up to 100,000 troops sent by governors as early as February. By May,
Jefferson Davis was pushing for 100,000 men under arms for one year or the
duration, and that was answered in kind by the U.S. Congress.[114]

In the first year of the war, both sides had far more volunteers than they
could effectively train and equip. After the initial enthusiasm faded,
reliance on the cohort of young men who came of age every year and wanted to
join was not enough. Both sides used a draft
law—[conscription](/wiki/Conscription "Conscription")—as a device to encourage
or force volunteering; relatively few were actually drafted and served. The
Confederacy passed a draft law in April 1862 for young men aged 18 to 35;
overseers of slaves, government officials, and clergymen were exempt.[115] The
U.S. Congress followed in July, authorizing a militia draft within a state
when it could not meet its quota with volunteers. European
[immigrants](/wiki/History_of_Immigration_to_the_United_States#Immigration_1790_to_1849
"History of Immigration to the United States") joined the [Union
Army](/wiki/Union_Army "Union Army") in large numbers, including 177,000 born
in Germany and 144,000 born in Ireland.[116]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Conf_dead_chancellorsville_edit1.jpg/180px-
Conf_dead_chancellorsville_edit1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Conf_dead_chancellorsville_edit1.jpg)

Confederate dead overrun at Marye's Heights, reoccupied next day May 4, 1863

When the Emancipation Proclamation went into effect in January 1863, ex-slaves
were energetically recruited by the states, and used to meet the state quotas.
States and local communities offered higher and higher cash bonuses for white
volunteers. Congress tightened the law in March 1863. Men selected in the
draft could provide substitutes or, until mid-1864, pay commutation money.
Many eligibles pooled their money to cover the cost of anyone drafted.
Families used the substitute provision to select which man should go into the
army and which should stay home. There was much evasion and overt resistance
to the draft, especially in Catholic areas. The great [draft riot in New York
City in July 1863](/wiki/New_York_Draft_Riots "New York Draft Riots") involved
Irish immigrants who had been signed up as citizens to swell the vote of the
[city's Democratic political machine](/wiki/Tammany_Hall "Tammany Hall"), not
realizing it made them liable for the draft.[117] Of the 168,649 men procured
for the Union through the draft, 117,986 were substitutes, leaving only 50,663
who had their personal services conscripted.[118]

In both the North and South, the draft laws were highly unpopular. In the
North, some 120,000 men evaded conscription, many of them fleeing to Canada,
and another 280,000 soldiers deserted during the war.[119] At least 100,000
Southerners deserted, or about 10 percent. In the South, many men deserted
temporarily to take care of their distressed families, then returned to their
units.[120] In the North, "bounty jumpers" enlisted to get the generous bonus,
deserted, then went back to a second recruiting station under a different name
to sign up again for a second bonus; 141 were caught and executed.[121]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/NYRiot.jpg/170px-
NYRiot.jpg)](/wiki/File:NYRiot.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NYRiot.jpg "Enlarge")

Rioters attacking a building during the [New York anti-draft
riots](/wiki/New_York_City_draft_riots "New York City draft riots") of 1863

From a tiny frontier force in 1860, the Union and Confederate armies had grown
into the "largest and most efficient armies in the world" within a few years.
European observers at the time dismissed them as amateur and unprofessional,
but British historian [John Keegan](/wiki/John_Keegan "John Keegan")'s
assessment is that each outmatched the French, Prussian and Russian armies of
the time, and but for the Atlantic, would have threatened any of them with
defeat.[122]

#### Motivation

Perman and Taylor (2010) say that historians are of two minds on why millions
of men seemed so eager to fight, suffer and die over four years:

> Some historians emphasize that Civil War soldiers were driven by political
> ideology, holding firm beliefs about the importance of liberty, Union, or
> state rights, or about the need to protect or to destroy slavery. Others
> point to less overtly political reasons to fight, such as the defense of
> one's home and family, or the honor and brotherhood to be preserved when
> fighting alongside other men. Most historians agree that no matter what a
> soldier thought about when he went into the war, the experience of combat
> affected him profoundly and sometimes altered his reasons for continuing the
> fight.[123]

#### Prisoners

Main article: [American Civil War prison
camps](/wiki/American_Civil_War_prison_camps "American Civil War prison
camps")

At the start of the civil war, a system of paroles operated. Captives agreed
not to fight until they were officially exchanged. Meanwhile, they were held
in camps run by their own army where they were paid but not allowed to perform
any military duties.[124] The system of exchanges collapsed in 1863 when the
Confederacy refused to exchange black prisoners. After that, about 56,000 of
the 409,000 POWs died in prisons during the war, accounting for nearly 10
percent of the conflict's fatalities.[125]

### Naval war

The small [U.S. Navy](/wiki/Union_Navy "Union Navy") of 1861 was rapidly
enlarged to 6,000 officers and 45,000 men in 1865, with 671 vessels, having a
tonnage of 510,396.[126][127] Its mission was to blockade Confederate ports,
take control of the river system, defend against Confederate raiders on the
high seas, and be ready for a possible war with the British [Royal
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy").[128] Meanwhile, the main riverine war
was fought in the West, where a series of major rivers gave access to the
Confederate heartland, if the U.S. Navy could take control. In the East, the
Navy supplied and moved army forces about, and occasionally shelled
Confederate installations.

#### Union blockade

Main article: [Union blockade](/wiki/Union_blockade "Union blockade")

[![A cartoon map of the South surrounded by a
snake.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Scott-
anaconda.jpg/330px-Scott-anaconda.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scott-anaconda.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Scott-anaconda.jpg "Enlarge")

General Scott's "[Anaconda Plan](/wiki/Anaconda_Plan "Anaconda Plan")" 1861\.
Tightening naval blockade, forcing rebels out of Missouri along the
Mississippi River, Kentucky Unionists sit on the fence, idled cotton industry
illustrated in Georgia.

By early 1861, General [Winfield Scott](/wiki/Winfield_Scott "Winfield Scott")
had devised the [Anaconda Plan](/wiki/Anaconda_Plan "Anaconda Plan") to win
the war with as little bloodshed as possible.[129] Scott argued that a Union
blockade of the main ports would weaken the Confederate economy. Lincoln
adopted parts of the plan, but he overruled Scott's caution about 90-day
volunteers. Public opinion, however, demanded an immediate attack by the army
to capture Richmond.[130]

In April 1861, Lincoln announced the Union blockade of all Southern ports;
commercial ships could not get insurance and regular traffic ended. The South
blundered in embargoing cotton exports in 1861 before the blockade was
effective; by the time they realized the mistake, it was too late. "King
Cotton" was dead, as the South could export less than 10 percent of its
cotton. The blockade shut down the ten Confederate seaports with railheads
that moved almost all the cotton, especially New Orleans, Mobile, and
Charleston. By June 1861, warships were stationed off the principal Southern
ports, and a year later nearly 300 ships were in service.[131]

##### Modern navy evolves

The Civil War occurred during the early stages of the industrial revolution
and subsequently many naval innovations emerged during this time, most notably
the advent of the [ironclad warship](/wiki/Ironclad_warship "Ironclad
warship"). It began when the Confederacy, knowing they had to meet or match
the Union's naval superiority, responded to the Union blockade by building or
converting more than 130 vessels, including twenty-six ironclads and floating
batteries.[132] Only half of these saw active service. Many were equipped with
ram bows, creating "ram fever" among Union squadrons wherever they threatened.
But in the face of overwhelming Union superiority and the Union's own ironclad
warships, they were unsuccessful.[133]

The Confederacy experimented with a [submarine](/wiki/CSS_Hunley "CSS
Hunley"), which did not work well,[134] and with building an ironclad ship,
the [CSS _Virginia_](/wiki/CSS_Virginia "CSS Virginia"), which was based on
rebuilding a sunken Union ship, the [_Merrimack_](/wiki/USS_Merrimack_\(1855\)
"USS Merrimack \(1855\)"). On its first foray on March 8, 1862, the _Virginia_
inflicted significant damage to the Union's wooden fleet, but the next day the
first Union ironclad, the [USS _Monitor_](/wiki/USS_Monitor "USS Monitor"),
arrived to challenge it in the [Chesapeake Bay](/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay
"Chesapeake Bay"). The resulting three hour [battle between the
Ironclads](/wiki/Battle_of_Hampton_Roads "Battle of Hampton Roads") was a
draw, but it marked the worldwide transition to ironclad warships.[135] Not
long after the battle the Confederacy was forced to scuttle the _Virginia_ to
prevent its capture, while the Union built many copies of the _Monitor_.
Lacking the technology and infrastructure to build effective warships, the
Confederacy attempted to obtain warships from Britain.[136]

##### Blockade runners

Main article: [Blockade runners of the American Civil
War](/wiki/Blockade_runners_of_the_American_Civil_War "Blockade runners of the
American Civil War")

British investors built small, fast, steam-driven [blockade
runners](/wiki/Blockade_runners_of_the_American_Civil_War "Blockade runners of
the American Civil War") that traded arms and luxuries brought in from Britain
through Bermuda, Cuba, and the Bahamas in return for high-priced cotton. Many
of the ships were designed for speed and were so small that only a small
amount of cotton went out.[137] When the Union Navy seized a blockade runner,
the ship and cargo were condemned as a [Prize of war](/wiki/Prize_of_war
"Prize of war") and sold, with the proceeds given to the Navy sailors; the
captured crewmen were mostly British and they were simply released.[138] The
Southern economy nearly collapsed during the war. There were multiple reasons
for this: the severe deterioration of food supplies, especially in cities, the
failure of Southern railroads, the loss of control of the main rivers,
foraging by Northern armies, and the seizure of animals and crops by
Confederate armies. Most historians agree that the blockade was a major factor
in ruining the Confederate economy, however, Wise argues that the blockade
runners provided just enough of a lifeline to allow Lee to continue fighting
for additional months, thanks to fresh supplies of 400,000 rifles, lead,
blankets, and boots that the homefront economy could no longer supply.[139]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/First_Charleston_Harbor.jpg/260px-
First_Charleston_Harbor.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_Charleston_Harbor.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:First_Charleston_Harbor.jpg "Enlarge")

Gunline of nine Union ironclads. [South Atlantic Blockading
Squadron](/wiki/Union_blockade#South_Atlantic_Blockading_Squadron "Union
blockade") off Charleston. Continuous blockade of all major ports was
sustained by North's overwhelming war production.

##### Economic impact

Surdam argues that the blockade was a powerful weapon that eventually ruined
the Southern economy, at the cost of few lives in combat. Practically, the
entire Confederate cotton crop was useless (although it was sold to Union
traders), costing the Confederacy its main source of income. Critical imports
were scarce and the coastal trade was largely ended as well.[140] The measure
of the blockade's success was not the few ships that slipped through, but the
thousands that never tried it. Merchant ships owned in Europe could not get
insurance and were too slow to evade the blockade; they simply stopped calling
at Confederate ports.[141]

To fight an offensive war, the Confederacy purchased ships from Britain,
converted them to warships, and raided American merchant ships in the Atlantic
and Pacific oceans. Insurance rates skyrocketed and the American flag
virtually disappeared from international waters. However, the same ships were
reflagged with European flags and continued unmolested.[133] After the war,
the U.S. demanded that Britain pay for the damage done, and Britain paid the
U.S. $15 million in 1871.[142]

#### Rivers

The 1862 Union strategy called for simultaneous advances along four axes:[143]

  1. McClellan would lead the main thrust in Virginia towards Richmond.
  2. Ohio forces would advance through Kentucky into Tennessee.
  3. The Missouri Department would drive south along the Mississippi River.
  4. The westernmost attack would originate from Kansas.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/NavalBattleOfFortPillow.jpg/320px-
NavalBattleOfFortPillow.jpg)](/wiki/File:NavalBattleOfFortPillow.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NavalBattleOfFortPillow.jpg "Enlarge")

Clashes on the rivers were melees of [ironclads](/wiki/Ironclads "Ironclads"),
[cottonclads](/wiki/Cottonclad_warship "Cottonclad warship"),
[gunboats](/wiki/Gunboats "Gunboats") and rams, complicated by torpedoes and
by [fire rafts](/wiki/Fire_ship "Fire ship").

[Ulysses Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant") used river
transport and [Andrew Foote's](/wiki/Andrew_H._Foote "Andrew H. Foote")
gunboats of the Western Flotilla to threaten the Confederacy's "Gibraltar of
the West" at Columbus, Kentucky. Though rebuffed at Belmont, Grant cut off
Columbus. The Confederates, lacking their own gunboats, were forced to retreat
and the Union took control of western Kentucky in March 1862.[144]

In addition to ocean-going warships coming up the Mississippi, the Union Navy
used timberclads, tinclads, and armored gunboats. Shipyards at Cairo,
Illinois, and St. Louis built new boats or modified steamboats for
action.[145] They took control of the Red, Tennessee, Cumberland, Mississippi,
and Ohio rivers after victories at [Fort Henry](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Henry
"Battle of Fort Henry") (February 6, 1862) and [Fort
Donelson](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Donelson "Battle of Fort Donelson") (February
11 to 16, 1862), and supplied Grant's forces as he moved into Tennessee. At
[Shiloh](/wiki/Battle_of_Shiloh "Battle of Shiloh") (Pittsburg Landing), in
Tennessee in April 1862, the Confederates made a surprise attack that pushed
Union forces against the river as night fell. Overnight, the Navy landed
additional reinforcements, and Grant counter-attacked. Grant and the Union won
a decisive victory—the first battle with the high casualty rates that would
repeat over and over.[146] [Memphis fell to Union
forces](/wiki/Battle_of_Memphis "Battle of Memphis") on June 6, 1862, and
became a key base for further advances south along the Mississippi River. On
April 24, 1862, U.S. Naval forces under [Farragut](/wiki/David_Farragut "David
Farragut") ran past Confederate defenses south of New Orleans. Confederate
forces abandoned the city, giving the Union a critical anchor in the deep
South.[147]

Naval forces assisted Grant in the long, complex [Vicksburg
Campaign](/wiki/Vicksburg_Campaign "Vicksburg Campaign") that resulted in the
Confederates surrendering at [Vicksburg,
Mississippi](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg, Mississippi") in July
1863, and in the Union fully controlling the Mississippi River soon
after.[148]

### Eastern theater

For more details on this topic, see [Eastern Theater of the American Civil
War](/wiki/Eastern_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Eastern Theater of the
American Civil War").

In one of the first highly visible battles, a march by Union troops under the
command of [Maj. Gen.](/wiki/Major_General "Major General") [Irvin
McDowell](/wiki/Irvin_McDowell "Irvin McDowell") on the Confederate forces
near Washington was repulsed.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Battle_of_Antietam_by_Thulstrup.jpg/220px-
Battle_of_Antietam_by_Thulstrup.jpg)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Antietam_by_Thulstrup.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Battle_of_Hampton_Roads_3g01752u.jpg/220px-
Battle_of_Hampton_Roads_3g01752u.jpg)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Hampton_Roads_3g01752u.jpg)

Left: The [Battle of Antietam](/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam "Battle of Antietam"),
the Civil War's deadliest one-day fight. Union troops committed piecemeal had
little effect.

Right: Confederate ironclads at [Norfolk](/wiki/Battle_of_Hampton_Roads
"Battle of Hampton Roads") and New Orleans dispersed blockade, until Union
ironclads could defeat them.

Maj. Gen. [George B. McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan "George B.
McClellan") took command of the Union [Army of the
Potomac](/wiki/Army_of_the_Potomac "Army of the Potomac") on July 26 (he was
briefly general-in-chief of all the Union armies, but was subsequently
relieved of that post in favor of Maj. Gen. [Henry W.
Halleck](/wiki/Henry_Halleck "Henry Halleck")), and the war began in earnest
in 1862. Upon the strong urging of President Lincoln to begin offensive
operations, McClellan attacked Virginia in the spring of 1862 by way of the
[peninsula](/wiki/Virginia_Peninsula "Virginia Peninsula") between the [York
River](/wiki/York_River_\(Virginia\) "York River \(Virginia\)") and [James
River](/wiki/James_River "James River"), southeast of Richmond. Although
McClellan's army reached the gates of Richmond in the [Peninsula
Campaign](/wiki/Peninsula_Campaign "Peninsula Campaign"),[149][150][151]
[Johnston](/wiki/Joseph_E._Johnston "Joseph E. Johnston") halted his advance
at the [Battle of Seven Pines](/wiki/Battle_of_Seven_Pines "Battle of Seven
Pines"), then General [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee") and
top subordinates [James Longstreet](/wiki/James_Longstreet "James Longstreet")
and Stonewall Jackson defeated McClellan in the [Seven Days
Battles](/wiki/Seven_Days_Battles "Seven Days Battles") and forced his
retreat.[152] The [Northern Virginia
Campaign](/wiki/Northern_Virginia_Campaign "Northern Virginia Campaign"),
which included the [Second Battle of Bull Run](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Bull_Run
"Second Battle of Bull Run"), ended in yet another victory for the South.[153]
McClellan resisted General-in-Chief Halleck's orders to send reinforcements to
[John Pope's](/wiki/John_Pope_\(military_officer\) "John Pope \(military
officer\)") Union [Army of Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Virginia "Army of
Virginia"), which made it easier for Lee's Confederates to defeat twice the
number of combined enemy troops.

Emboldened by Second Bull Run, the Confederacy made its first invasion of the
North. General Lee led 45,000 men of the [Army of Northern
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia "Army of Northern Virginia") across
the [Potomac River](/wiki/Potomac_River "Potomac River") into Maryland on
September 5. Lincoln then restored Pope's troops to McClellan. McClellan and
Lee fought at the [Battle of Antietam](/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam "Battle of
Antietam") near [Sharpsburg](/wiki/Sharpsburg,_Maryland "Sharpsburg,
Maryland"), Maryland, on September 17, 1862, the bloodiest single day in
United States military history.[152][154] Lee's army, checked at last,
returned to Virginia before McClellan could destroy it. Antietam is considered
a Union victory because it halted Lee's invasion of the North and provided an
opportunity for Lincoln to announce his [Emancipation
Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation
Proclamation").[155]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Bayonet-
charge-1250.jpg/220px-Bayonet-charge-1250.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bayonet-
charge-1250.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bayonet-charge-1250.jpg "Enlarge")

Union forces performing a bayonet charge, 1862

When the cautious McClellan failed to follow up on Antietam, he was replaced
by Maj. Gen. [Ambrose Burnside](/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside "Ambrose Burnside").
Burnside was soon defeated at the [Battle of
Fredericksburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Fredericksburg "Battle of
Fredericksburg")[156] on December 13, 1862, when more than 12,000 Union
soldiers were killed or wounded during repeated futile frontal assaults
against Marye's Heights. After the battle, Burnside was replaced by Maj. Gen.
[Joseph Hooker](/wiki/Joseph_Hooker "Joseph Hooker").

Hooker, too, proved unable to defeat Lee's army; despite outnumbering the
Confederates by more than two to one, he was humiliated in the [Battle of
Chancellorsville](/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville "Battle of
Chancellorsville") in May 1863.[157] Gen. Stonewall Jackson was shot in the
arm by accidental friendly fire during the battle and subsequently died of
complications.[158] Gen. Hooker was replaced by Maj. Gen. [George
Meade](/wiki/George_Meade "George Meade") during Lee's second invasion of the
North, in June. Meade defeated Lee at the [Battle of
Gettysburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg "Battle of Gettysburg") (July 1 to 3,
1863).[159] This was the bloodiest battle of the war, and has been called the
war's [turning point](/wiki/Turning_point_of_the_American_Civil_War "Turning
point of the American Civil War"). [Pickett's Charge](/wiki/Pickett%27s_Charge
"Pickett's Charge") on July 3 is often considered the [high-water mark of the
Confederacy](/wiki/High-water_mark_of_the_Confederacy "High-water mark of the
Confederacy") because it signaled the collapse of serious Confederate threats
of victory. Lee's army suffered 28,000 casualties (versus Meade's
23,000).[160] However, Lincoln was angry that Meade failed to intercept Lee's
retreat, and after Meade's inconclusive fall campaign, Lincoln turned to the
Western Theater for new leadership. At the same time, the Confederate
stronghold of Vicksburg surrendered, giving the Union control of the
Mississippi River, permanently isolating the western Confederacy, and
producing the new leader Lincoln needed, [Ulysses S.
Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant").

### Western theater

For more details on this topic, see [Western Theater of the American Civil
War](/wiki/Western_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Western Theater of the
American Civil War").

While the Confederate forces had numerous successes in the Eastern Theater,
they were defeated many times in the West. They were driven from Missouri
early in the war as a result of the [Battle of Pea
Ridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Pea_Ridge "Battle of Pea Ridge").[161] [Leonidas
Polk](/wiki/Leonidas_Polk "Leonidas Polk")'s invasion of
[Columbus](/wiki/Columbus,_Kentucky "Columbus, Kentucky"), Kentucky ended
Kentucky's policy of neutrality and turned that state against the Confederacy.
[Nashville](/wiki/Nashville,_Tennessee "Nashville, Tennessee") and central
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee") fell to the Union early in 1862,
leading to attrition of local food supplies and livestock and a breakdown in
social organization.

Chickamauga.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chickamauga.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/New_Orleans_h76369k.jpg/220px-
New_Orleans_h76369k.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Orleans_h76369k.jpg)

Left: The [Battle of Chickamauga](/wiki/Battle_of_Chickamauga "Battle of
Chickamauga"), the highest two-day losses. Confederate victory held off Union

Right: [New Orleans
captured](/wiki/Capture_of_New_Orleans#New_Orleans_takes_a_stand "Capture of
New Orleans"). Union ironclads forced passage, sank Confederate fleet,
destroyed batteries, held docks for Army.

The [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") was opened to
Union traffic to the southern border of Tennessee with the taking of [Island
No. 10](/wiki/Battle_of_Island_Number_Ten "Battle of Island Number Ten") and
[New Madrid](/wiki/New_Madrid,_Missouri "New Madrid, Missouri"), Missouri, and
then [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"). In
April 1862, the [Union Navy](/wiki/Union_Navy "Union Navy") captured New
Orleans,[162] which allowed Union forces to begin moving up the Mississippi.
Only the fortress city of [Vicksburg](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg,
Mississippi"), Mississippi, prevented Union control of the entire river.

General [Braxton Bragg](/wiki/Braxton_Bragg "Braxton Bragg")'s second
Confederate invasion of Kentucky ended with a meaningless victory over Maj.
Gen. [Don Carlos Buell](/wiki/Don_Carlos_Buell "Don Carlos Buell") at the
[Battle of Perryville](/wiki/Battle_of_Perryville "Battle of Perryville"),
although Bragg was forced to end his attempt at invading Kentucky and retreat
due to lack of support for the Confederacy in that state.[163] Bragg was
narrowly defeated by Maj. Gen. [William Rosecrans](/wiki/William_Rosecrans
"William Rosecrans") at the [Battle of Stones
River](/wiki/Battle_of_Stones_River "Battle of Stones River") in
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee").[164]

The one clear Confederate victory in the West was the [Battle of
Chickamauga](/wiki/Battle_of_Chickamauga "Battle of Chickamauga"). Bragg,
reinforced by Lt. Gen. [James Longstreet](/wiki/James_Longstreet "James
Longstreet")'s corps (from Lee's army in the east), defeated Rosecrans,
despite the heroic defensive stand of Maj. Gen. [George Henry
Thomas](/wiki/George_Henry_Thomas "George Henry Thomas"). Rosecrans retreated
to [Chattanooga](/wiki/Chattanooga,_Tennessee "Chattanooga, Tennessee"), which
Bragg then besieged.

The Union's key strategist and tactician in the West was [Ulysses S.
Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant"), who won victories at Forts
[Henry](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Henry "Battle of Fort Henry") and
[Donelson](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Donelson "Battle of Fort Donelson") (by which
the Union seized control of the [Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee_River "Tennessee
River") and [Cumberland](/wiki/Cumberland_River "Cumberland River") Rivers);
the [Battle of Shiloh](/wiki/Battle_of_Shiloh "Battle of Shiloh");[165] and
the [Battle of Vicksburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg"),[166]
which cemented Union control of the Mississippi River and is considered one of
the [turning points](/wiki/Turning_point_of_the_American_Civil_War "Turning
point of the American Civil War") of the war. Grant marched to the relief of
Rosecrans and defeated Bragg at the [Third Battle of
Chattanooga](/wiki/Chattanooga_Campaign "Chattanooga Campaign"),[167] driving
Confederate forces out of Tennessee and opening a route to Atlanta and the
heart of the Confederacy.

### Trans-Mississippi

For more details on Missouri in the Civil War, see [Trans-Mississippi Theater
of the American Civil War](/wiki/Trans-
Mississippi_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Trans-Mississippi Theater of
the American Civil War").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Battle_of_Lawrence.png/220px-
Battle_of_Lawrence.png)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Lawrence.png)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Wilson%27s_Creek_charge_of_1st_Iowa.jpg/220px-
Wilson%27s_Creek_charge_of_1st_Iowa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wilson%27s_Creek_charge_of_1st_Iowa.jpg)

Left: [Quantrill's Raid](/wiki/Lawrence_Massacre "Lawrence Massacre") captured
a hotel in free-state Kansas for a day in a town of 2,000, burned 185
buildings, killed 182 men and boys.[168]

Right: [Nathaniel Lyon](/wiki/Nathaniel_Lyon "Nathaniel Lyon") secured St.
Louis docks and arsenal, led Union forces to expel Missouri Confederate forces
and government.[169]

Extensive [guerrilla warfare](/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare "Guerrilla warfare")
characterized the trans-Mississippi region, as the Confederacy lacked the
troops and the logistics to support regular armies that could challenge Union
control.[170] Roving Confederate bands such as [Quantrill's
Raiders](/wiki/Quantrill%27s_Raiders "Quantrill's Raiders") terrorized the
countryside, striking both military installations and civilian
settlements.[171] The "Sons of Liberty" and "Order of the American Knights"
attacked pro-Union people, elected officeholders, and unarmed uniformed
soldiers. These partisans could not be entirely driven out of the state of
Missouri until an entire regular Union infantry division was engaged.

By 1864, these violent activities harmed the nationwide anti-war movement
organizing against the re-election of Lincoln. Missouri not only stayed in the
Union, Lincoln took 70 percent of the vote for re-election.[168]

Numerous small-scale military actions south and west of Missouri sought to
control [Indian Territory](/wiki/Indian_Territory_in_the_American_Civil_War
"Indian Territory in the American Civil War") and [New Mexico
Territory](/wiki/New_Mexico_Territory_in_the_American_Civil_War "New Mexico
Territory in the American Civil War") for the Union. The Union repulsed
Confederate incursions into New Mexico in 1862, and the exiled Arizona
government withdrew into Texas. In the Indian Territory, civil war broke out
within tribes. About 12,000 Indian warriors fought for the Confederacy, and
smaller numbers for the Union.[172] The most prominent Cherokee was Brigadier
General [Stand Watie](/wiki/Stand_Watie "Stand Watie"), the last Confederate
general to surrender.[173]

After the fall of [Vicksburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg")
in July 1863, General [Kirby Smith](/wiki/Edmund_Kirby_Smith "Edmund Kirby
Smith") in Texas was informed by Jefferson Davis that he could expect no
further help from east of the Mississippi River. Although he lacked resources
to beat Union armies, he built up a formidable arsenal at Tyler, along with
his own Kirby Smithdom economy, a virtual "independent fiefdom" in Texas,
including railroad construction and international smuggling. The Union in turn
did not directly engage him.[174] Its 1864 [Red River
Campaign](/wiki/Red_River_Campaign "Red River Campaign") to take Shreveport,
Louisiana was a failure and Texas remained in Confederate hands throughout the
war.

### End of the war

#### Conquest of Virginia

At the beginning of 1864, Lincoln made Grant commander of all Union armies.
Grant made his headquarters with the Army of the Potomac, and put Maj. Gen.
[William Tecumseh Sherman](/wiki/William_Tecumseh_Sherman "William Tecumseh
Sherman") in command of most of the western armies. Grant understood the
concept of [total war](/wiki/Total_war "Total war") and believed, along with
Lincoln and Sherman, that only the utter defeat of Confederate forces and
their economic base would end the war.[175] This was total war not in killing
civilians but rather in taking provisions and forage and destroying homes,
farms, and railroads, that Grant said "would otherwise have gone to the
support of secession and rebellion. This policy I believe exercised a material
influence in hastening the end."[176] Grant devised a coordinated strategy
that would strike at the entire Confederacy from multiple directions. Generals
[George Meade](/wiki/George_Meade "George Meade") and [Benjamin
Butler](/wiki/Benjamin_Butler_\(politician\) "Benjamin Butler \(politician\)")
were ordered to move against Lee near Richmond, General [Franz
Sigel](/wiki/Franz_Sigel "Franz Sigel") (and later [Philip
Sheridan](/wiki/Philip_Sheridan "Philip Sheridan")) were to [attack the
Shenandoah Valley](/wiki/Valley_Campaigns_of_1864 "Valley Campaigns of 1864"),
General Sherman was to capture Atlanta and march to the sea (the Atlantic
Ocean), Generals [George Crook](/wiki/George_Crook "George Crook") and
[William W. Averell](/wiki/William_W._Averell "William W. Averell") were to
operate against railroad supply lines in [West Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia
"West Virginia"), and Maj. Gen. [Nathaniel P.
Banks](/wiki/Nathaniel_Prentice_Banks "Nathaniel Prentice Banks") was to
capture [Mobile](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama "Mobile, Alabama"), Alabama.[177]

The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Peacemakers_1868.jpg)
